Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Genomic approaches to comparative phylogeography in a biodiversity hotspot
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses how, when, and why organisms diversify and become distinct species. The focal system is an under-studied biodiversity hotspot: Mexican pine-oak woodlands. Sampling of 34 emblematic vertebrates will occur across four major mountain ranges in Mexico and linked regions in the United States. Species include 21 birds, 4 amphibians, and 9 reptiles. DNA data will be collected using novel techniques that capture hundreds of genomic regions, which will be assayed to determine: (1) if there are overlooked cryptic species; (2) whether common barriers (e.g. lowland regions) have influenced diversification across species; and (3) whether the timing of species origins coincides with periods of mountain building or glacial cycling through deep time.

This study will uncover new biodiversity in a part of the world that is known for its species richness and that is under severe threat from habitat loss. Knowing the basic units of biodiversity is the first step toward mitigating such threats. This study will also help understand how biodiversity is generated and over what timescale. All specimens collected will be deposited in natural history collections at two U.S. museums, and will be available for many other studies -- natural history collections are public repositories of biodiversity with virtually limitless future potential on subjects ranging from public health and disease to basic science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In our project we used large amounts of DNA sequence data to study the evolutionary history of two groups of emblematic vertebrates inhabiting one of the world’s endangered biodiversity hotspots, Mexican pine-oak forests. Specifically, we generated and analyzed millions of base-pairs of DNA from over 900 samples representing eleven groups of birds, three groups of amphibians, and seven groups of reptiles. These data will provide us with an unprecedented assessment of how very different groups of animals that live in the same habitats, have responded to shared historical events that occurred over the past several million years.

 

Our project on the Mexican highlands involved collaborations among curators, professors, postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduate students at two universities in the United States and two universities in Mexico. We provided training for two postdocs and several visiting researchers from Mexico in methods to generate and analyze next-generation DNA sequence data. Postdocs in turn helped train graduate and undergraduate students. The specimens and tissues obtained during our research have been deposited in the Moore Lab of Zoology and Burke Museum of Natural History, which house the world’s largest collections of Mexican birds. We used these museum specimens to promote the value of natural history collections in education. Through these museums, our specimens are also available to researchers across the world.

 

We have assembled data sets for all focal species, which took a significant amount of computational power. We have only begun to publish the results of this research.  A paper on the genetic diversity of Mexican Jays across the Mexican highlands is currently in review, while a similar paper on a Mexican endemic skink complex is about to be submitted for review.  As we continue to move forward with our project, we will continue to use a variety of computer programs to infer genetic structure within each species. Like pieces to a puzzle, each species reveals a unique historical element of the assembly of the Mexican highlands. Our ultimate goal is to compare the evolutionary histories of all species to better understand the events that shaped the present-day biological diversity in the Mexican highland system.


Last Modified: 05/26/2016
Modified by: John T Klicka

Specifically, we generated and analyzed millions of base-pairs of DNA from over 900 samples representing eleven groups of birds, three groups of amphibians, and seven groups of reptiles. These data will provide us with an unprecedented assessment of how very different groups of animals that live in the same habitats, have responded to shared historical events that occurred over the past several million years. Our project on the Mexican highlands involved collaborations among curators, professors, postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduate students at two universities in the United States and two universities in Mexico. We provided training for two postdocs and several visiting researchers from Mexico in methods to generate and analyze next-generation DNA sequence data. Postdocs in turn helped train graduate and undergraduate students. The specimens and tissues obtained during our research have been deposited in the Moore Lab of Zoology and Burke Museum of Natural History, which house the worldÆs largest collections of Mexican birds. We used these museum specimens to promote the value of natural history collections in education. Through these museums, our specimens are also available to researchers across the world.
